hypotheses: H1: The linear association between violence and election fraud will be positive.
H* (SCORE focal test): The quadratic association between violence and election fraud will be negative.
claim.hypotheses_location: Page 58, introduction: Our theory has two testable predictions.
claim.statement: The relationship between violence and election fraud follows an inverted U-shape: fraud increases with violence up to a certain level, then decreases.
claim.statement_location: Page 54, paragraph: Our theory, therefore, predicts that the relationship between election fraud and violence follows an inverted U-shape.

data.source: Election results, SIGACT reports on violence incidents
data.sample_size: 398 districts, varying number of polling stations
data.notes: Data on violence incidents from ISAF SIGACT reports and recount of a sample of ballot boxes used for fraud detection validation.

method.description: The study leveraged forensic fraud detection methods based on last-digit analysis of election results, validated against a recount of ballot boxes, and analyzed the relationship between violence and election fraud across districts.
steps: Collect SIGACT reports on violence incidents around election day.
Gather electoral results from polling stations.
Apply forensic fraud detection using last-digit analysis.
Validate the fraud detection measure against recount data.
Conduct regression analysis to test the inverted U-shaped hypothesis and spatial displacement of fraud.
method.outcome_variable: Election fraud detected via last-digit patterns and recount
method.independent_variables: Levels of violence around election day
method.tools_software: R software was implied but not explicitly mentioned.

results.summary: Findings support the prediction that relationship between election fraud and violence follows an inverted U-shape. Fraud initially increases with violence up to a point but decreases once violence surpasses that level.

metadata.original_paper_title: Violence and Election Fraud: Evidence from Afghanistan
metadata.original_paper_data: Replication data will be available at http://dvn.iq.harvard.edu/dvn/dv/nilsw upon publication.
